ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Semester-long semi-guided research on a topic of your own choosing. Valuable chance not only to undertake your own research, but also to get useful feedback from instructor and fellow seminar participants.Yes, I would recommend this course.
I would recommend it to other students. It is a great class for anyone who is interested in Japanese history or anyone who wants to learn how to do serious research.

I would absolutely recommend this class, especially to people who have an idea for a project but might want suggestions on sources, methodology, or other issues. Although I am not a history specialist, I found the class highly accessible. It is, however, a class from which you will get out what you put in. The amount and quality of research is more or less up to you, so you will need to be a self-starter to perform well.
Yes, I would recommend this class unhesitatingly.
It is a research seminar specialized in Japanese history. I would recommend it to any student interested in delving deeply into a topic in Japanese history.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The opportunity to undertake independent research was extremely valuable; it familiarized me with a variety of scholars and sources and helped sharpen my potential research goals for my future PhD studies. More fundamentally, it was good practice in performing a semester-long research project, and even more fundamentally, it allowed me to put my ability to read pre-modern Japanese sources to the test.
This class is great training for me. I not only learned a lot of knowledge, but also learned how to do serious research.

This was a great course for deepening my comfort level with and understanding of history methodology, and the process of conducting historical research. I was able to learn to use new resources. I used microfilm for the first time, and also made my first visit to the Library of Congress to access hard-to-find materials. I feel much more comfortable attacking the historical side of problems, now.

The research paper produced in this seminar provided a basis for further developing my dissertation topic, and forced me to think about the different bodies of literature that need to be addressed in my prospectus.
